name: Charlie Shader

summary:
Communicate With Confidence In Written And Spoken (Business) English!

My work has always demanded correct (Business) English-language usage in a wide variety of settings.  I love seeing clients enjoy learning and building their confidence to express themselves clearly.  For me, â€œplayingâ€ with the language and â€œpuzzlingâ€ over text is fun!

Let me make your work easier.  Translating, writing and editing are very demanding, especially when trying to get your Dutch ideas across in (business) English.  Small to medium-size businesses need to have high confidence in their written communication with colleagues and (potential) clients.

My other passion, aside from working with text, is helping individuals develop English-language skills.  Having self-confidence in your skills also helps you use English more effectively:  communicate fluently, easily express yourself in conversation and presenting to a group.  In addition, a range of knowledge, literature, art, and social awareness becomes available for your own use.

My approach to our work is collaborative, with an eye towards individual needs. Sometimes, in the beginning, I may have more questions than answers.

My services include:
editing and writing (business) your English-language texts,
light Dutch â€“ English Translation keeping in mind cultural differences,
training for English-language presenting and conversational English,
Cambridge Advanced Certificate and Cambridge IELTS exam training,
training for small groups or teams,
experience in bi-lingual education and tutoring and
introducing young Dutch children to using English before becoming expats

summary:
Hi, I am Dr. Lieke Verheijen, assistant professor in Communication and Information Studies at Radboud University in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, as well as program director of the master CIW there. I am also one of the five members of the Spelling Committee of the Dutch Language Union ('Taalunie').

My research is about language use in personal and professional computer-mediated communication, as well as its impact on literacy, and particularly the use of emoji in CMC.

I have obtained degrees in English Language and Culture (BA & MA, both cum laude), Language and Communication (Research Master, summa cum laude), and Dutch Applied Linguistics (PhD).

My skills, besides research in linguistics, include data analysis, (academic) writing, editing, translation, teaching, research/information/time/self-/project management, project/strategic/event planning, events organisation, problem solving, analytical skills, critical thinking, presentation skills, public speaking, teamwork, and interpersonal skills.

name: Suzanne Peraino
field of studies 1: English and American Language and Literature
field of studies 2: English and American Language and Literature
summary:
My current professional focus and research:
 Inter-cultural awareness and pedagogical skills in the EAP classroom, specifically focusing on Chinese academic degree-seekers in Anglophone programs and academies.

Since 2010, following from my ancillary university focus on Chinese language and culture, I and my colleagues Dr. Mark Vitullo and Dr. Yao (Amy) Hsiao have been involved in several projects relating to Chinese exchange students and their English language acquisition and production skills within the Anglophone academic environment (specifically EAP writing/oral skills at Tilburg University). We are currently exploring the practical English language acquisition and production difficulties with which these students struggle and which hinder their success in Anglophone programs. 

Our goal is twofold:
1)	 To offer EAP (English for academic purposes) university teachers information about certain Chinese (Mandarin) language characteristics, Chinese rhetorical essay structures and logical conventions of idea development that Chinese exchange students learn in China. This information should enable the EAP teacher to identity and modify potential interference patterns during EAP courses.
2)	To develop practical classroom methods to support and coach Chinese exchange students more efficiently and effectively so that they can acquire the academic English skills they need to succeed in the global, primarily Anglophone, academic environment. 
My academic interest in this has its root in my Bachelorâ€™s education in Asian Studies, as well as my current work with Chinese PhD candidates at Tilburg University.

During my undergraduate education, I took several courses in Mandarin Chinese. I have now resumed Mandarin language classes to gain a better insight into basic Mandarin  structures and pronunciation.

summary:
I love words. I love reading them, writing them, comparing them, meticulously choosing the right one among them. I love analysing their meaning, their deepest and most hidden connotations, and revealing their true essence. I love reducing them to their minimal constituent parts to later rebuild them renewed, refreshed. I love combining words, transforming them, playing with them, dusting the old ones, welcoming the new ones. I love making them say.

And thatâ€™s what I do.

To successfully communicate your message and make it resonate with your ideal Spanish-speaking audience, you need someone with expert knowledge of the original language and culture, impeccable writing and communication skills and, above all, full understanding of the complexity and diversity of the Spanish-speaking world.

Thatâ€™s why I can help you!

As a native speaker of Spanish, I put my love for my language and culture into good use by helping companies, publishers, and authors reach their Spanish-speaking targeted audience. I bridge the gap between cultures by translating English, French, and Italian texts into accurate, flawless Spanish.

Letâ€™s unlock a world of infinite opportunities!

Contact me for the following services:
- English, French, and Italian to Spanish translation
- Spanish editing and proofreading
- Subtitling

More information:
info@teresitadevedia.com

summary:
I'm passionate about understanding and addressing inequalities, whether through teaching, writing or having humble, honest conversations with people from all walks of life. I am seeking opportunities to promote diversity, inclusion, intercultural exchange and the arts and to advocate for disadvantaged communities.

My doctoral research, for which I received the prestigious Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarship, focused on stereotypes of race, gender and sexuality. I like to teach university and college students about power relationships, identities, and forms of difference. I am committed to doing meaningful work that promotes inclusion, honors diversity, welcomes differences rather than erases them, and helps people become their most equitable, aware selves. I am open to opportunities in the cultural, public, academic, non-profit or profit sector. I have special expertise in literary studies, cultural studies, critical race studies, gender studies and Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, and extensive experience with diverse immigrant communities.

name: Michael Glennon
skills: ['Research', 'Lesgeven', 'Management', 'Hoger onderwijs', 'Sociologie']
summary:
I work in several areas: language coaching and scientific writing support for students and professionals, teaching social theory and social scientific research methods to students in higher education, and exploring the relationship between language and society with a particular emphasis on the subject of children and linguistic diversity in European urban areas.
  
Language Coaching and Writing Support: I provide language coaching for groups and individuals seeking  improvement and greater confidence in their use of academic English. I also offer support services for professionals and students working on specific scientific writing and/or formal academic English language texts, e.g. scientific articles, dissertations, theses, lectures and presentations, reports, proposals and etcetera. Additionally, I offer translation of reports, white papers or other documents for education and research.
 
E-learning, Sociology, and Higher Education: I possess more than twelve years of experience in online instruction. This experience includes teaching sociology at a college level to a wide variety of students for universities and colleges in the American Midwest, and the development of original online courses covering a wide range of topics relevant to the social sciences. Presently my course design efforts focus on enhancing the accessibility of course content. Making sure content is accessible not only to people with different learning styles, but also to people with impairments.   

Researcher and Social Scientist: I have specialized education and experience in the use of ethnographic and discourse analytic research methods. In the past I applied these skills to a social scientific research  on the subject of community based services for people with intellectual disabilities, and to the cultural politics of autism and autistic rights. Presently I am designing a framework for a comparative analysis of experiences raising multilingual children in the Netherlands and Germany.

name: Anna Kaal
skills: ['Teaching', 'English', 'Linguistics', 'Literature', 'Dutch', 'Translation', 'Journalism', 'Research', 'Language Teaching', 'Qualitative Research', 'Editing', 'Academic Writing', 'Lecturing', 'Intercultural Communication']
summary:
As a teacher educator and researcher at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, I work with pre-service and in-service teachers to translate knowledge about language and language learning to their (foreign) language classrooms. An essential theme in my work is the notion â€˜language awarenessâ€™, which can perhaps best be described as â€˜looking at the world through linguistic glassesâ€™ â€“ which knowledge about language do we all need in order to think critically about, but also enjoy, the language we use? I am also interested in the way (student) teachers reflect on their practice. 

I studied English language and culture (MA) and Communication and Information Sciences (BA) at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. I continued with a PhD in cognitive linguistics on the use of metaphor in  conversations. After obtaining an Educational MA, I taught English and Literature to secondary school students for 4 years.

At the moment I am teaching in our educational master programmes on the topics of narrativity and LA and their potential for language classrooms, on language pedagogy and general pedagogy and on teacher reflection. I am co-supervising two PhDs on language education and teacher and learner language awareness. I am working on metaphor elicitation to raise studentsâ€™ language awareness and teachersâ€™ perceptions of practice; other research includes the use of goal system reflection.   

Through organizing conferences and working with professional learning communities of (student) teachers me and my colleagues try to close the gap between theory and practice. I was one of the main organizers of the 2017 conference â€˜Look both ways: narrative and metaphor in educationâ€™ (an edited volume stemming from this conference was published with Routledge) and the ALA2018 conference â€˜Towards Language Aware Citizenshipâ€™.

My muldisciplinary academic and professional background represents the irreplaceable source of every decision I make. Indeed, Multidisciplinarity provided me fundamental tools for analysis, evaluation and action in diversified, complex and fragile contexts. I believe that the human added value stands in people's ideas and values and how these come from multiple varied knowledge and experience at all levels and all contexts. This is who I am as a person and professional. I am looking for a positive and stimulating work environment where I can share my thoughts, my knowledge, my experience and learn from others, working hard to make a real difference and have a positive impact on the global society.
